title: Heading downhill
pros: Mostly this is an easy going environment.  There is stress, but not excessive and most upper management (director level) care about their teams.
cons: Senior management is out of touch with the people that work in the store support center and probably the stores too. If it were true the change would be unnecessary since everyone would just come in.  It's crazy how 90% of my meetings are on teams and not in person.  It's just stupid management that will hurt DG in the long run.  Back out to the job market I guess.
advice_to_management: Be visible.  I rarely see VPs and they require us to be in the office when many aren't there themselves.  Go back to hybrid working conditions.

title: The store manager is trying but is limited by higher-ups
pros: Flexible scheduling for those who study or have other duties
cons:
Poor organization, management trying to push you harder and work faster despite knowing their employees have debilitating injuries. 

Expect to work with 1 other person at most during your shift.

Upper management urging store manager to fire low productivity workers while they're already struggling to hire, yet refuses to pay people higher wages. 

The back storage area is filled to the brim, you seriously cannot get through that area. The inventory ordering system seems to be at least partially automated and keeps sending the same items even though they never sell - it's very flawed and the place is not run well. While I was there, it seemed that the manager was at least trying, but upper management does not give many resources
advice_to_management: For upper management, please pay staff better, both the store associates and the store manager, they deserve higher wages for what they're going through working here. Better pay and better working conditions. Give the store higher budgets to allow for more employees to work simultaneously so the back warehouse area can also be sorted out.

title: Lack of understanding and support from management

cons:
Management after the first manager left was unsupportive and dismissive.
Constantly expected to do multiple people‚Äôs jobs at once.
No consideration for employees who work best focusing on one task at a time.
Communication issues and lack of appreciation for good work.
When I explained that I am autistic and have anxiety, accommodations or understanding were not provided.
Repeatedly pushed beyond reasonable limits, which created unnecessary stress.
advice_to_management: Listen to your employees and recognize individual strengths. Not everyone works the same way, and productivity improves when people are assigned tasks they do well instead of being overloaded. Be more understanding of mental health and neurodiversity, and don‚Äôt ignore employees who are genuinely trying and putting in effort. Appreciation and basic respect go a long way toward retaining good workers.

title: It completely depends on your location and team
pros: -If you have a good team, dollar general can be a fairly straightforward retail job that offers a broad range of skills needed for day-to-day operations in a relatively friendly work environment. I really liked my team and customers overall, and it offered me an opportunity to get started again after a gap in my resume with consideration for my health issues. They were extremely supportive and I was so thankful for the opportunity; but that only applies to this location, not the broader company.
cons:
-Since staffing is so light as a policy, not only do you juggle many hats at all times, but it can be a safety hazard. (A coworker may not hear you fall or a customer can easily corner you.)
-Female employees were made to feel unsafe by customers at times and coworkers had to watch each other's backs, as the manager would not ban them unless it happened in front of her. She was often also a victim of this behavior and was trying her best, it was a difficult situation all-around.
-DG Corp cares more for profits than employee safety and cameras are to catch employee theft, not monitor and document workplace safety/harassment.
-Shifts were often staffed by 1-3 employees max, with people often opening alone. Corporate limits of assignable hours were cited as a constant issue by management.
advice_to_management: -Make a formal method of complaint for inappropriate customer interactions to be documented and acted on so this isn't an ongoing issue. It emboldens these creeps when there's no consequence.

title: Hardest you‚Äôll ever work for the lowest you‚Äôll ever be paid
pros: Fantastic job security because no one wants to work here, for many, many very good reasons.
cons: Almost everything else.  The company has zero consistency, and does not appear to be serious about improving anything at all.  At this point it‚Äôs more of a ponzi scheme.  Their same-store year-over-year growth is around 1%, because when you only build in small towns that do not grow in population, your stores‚Äô customer base never increases, but to attract investment you must show growth.  This is why they keep building new stores.  So they need the investment to build stores, but they need to build stores to show growth to attract investment.  All this means is this company is a ‚Äúgrowth‚Äù company and not a ‚Äúretail‚Äù company, meaning they do not care about their stores at all beyond the first year, which means they do not care about their employees‚Äô wellbeing at all, so much so that they treat employees as an expense they‚Äôd rather not have.
advice_to_management: Honestly, because it‚Äôs a ‚Äúgrowth‚Äù company and not a ‚Äúretail‚Äù company, keep doing what you‚Äôre doing.  It‚Äôs up to employees to figure out your game and decide whether or not they want to participate.

title: Could have been better...
pros: Acquired understanding of store operations such as inventory control, cash handling, and loss prevention. This varied greatly from experience in a big-box store, and it was an interesting change in work atmosphere.
cons:
The job fostered a culture where employees were expected to prioritize the company above all else, leaving little room for independence.

Compensation was limited to base pay, as opportunities for wage progression were not provided or explained.

Despite bringing significant years of retail experience, the role did not provide opportunities that reflected prior skills and contributions.

Management initially communicated that my role was being elevated; however, the upgrade did not occur, and further explanation was not given.

Company guidelines were not always fully adhered to at the location level, which affected workflow and expectations.

There were ongoing issues with morale at the store level, stemming from leadership and communication challenges.

There were situations where inaccurate assumptions led to misplaced accountability.
advice_to_management:
Acknowledge the skills and background employees bring with them. Providing fair opportunities for wage growth and advancement shows that experience is valued and encourages retention.

When discussing promotions, upgrades, or policy changes, clear communication and consistent follow-through build trust and credibility. Employees thrive when they understand the reasons behind decisions.

Ensuring that store policies are followed fairly and consistently helps create stability, reduces confusion, and builds employee confidence in leadership.

A positive work environment depends on open communication, respect, and recognition. Investing in team morale leads to higher motivation and better overall performance.

Demonstrating accountability, fairness, and professionalism sets the tone for the entire team and strengthens workplace culture.

title: District Manager
pros: This company gives you just about every tool possible to succeed. I have never seen a more patient and focused company in my life. You can jump on the Wal-Mart express and believe that they are 'creating jobs' but this company truly is doing thar. They are not shutting down stores, down sizing, and leaving 25-50% of their employees out of luck. Dollar General is changing the face of America and hopefully soon the globe because they improvise for human error already. I feel truly blessed, proud, and determined to work at this company. I came here a young African American man who dropped the competition for personal reasons and knew that I was sacrificing a pay cut. I realized quickly that that money I gave up was nothing compared to the experience and opportunity this company has to offer. I tell anyone that has a sense of pride, stuck behind fear, hope and possibility at this company, it is definitely possible. I worked from the bottom to my current position and to be honest I don't regret a single bit of it. Come experience a real company if you really really want your hard work to pay off.

pros:

cons:

‚Ä¢ Irresponsible Store Mangers (varies by location, but majority of the time all of them)
‚Ä¢ No consistent scheduling
‚Ä¢ Retaliation 
‚Ä¢ Mangers being pinned for "loss of product" even in bad areas
‚Ä¢ WORKERS UNDERPAID 
‚Ä¢ Favoritism in upper management 
‚Ä¢ TIME THEFT for Store Mangers 
‚Ä¢ Disregard for employees safety 
‚Ä¢ Poor building management
‚Ä¢ ADVISES AGAINST UNIONIZING
‚Ä¢ work life balance
‚Ä¢ START DATE OF PAY
‚Ä¢ holiday pay dates and special pays
‚Ä¢ The stores on fire? Oh it didn't burn down? Just air it out and reopen. Oh, you said you'll literally quit on the spot if you have to do that? That's okay, just close the store.
‚Ä¢ oh you see rat droppings? Just close your eyes and keep going. Oh that product totally didn't come from a moldy fridge with 10 day old spilled milk. 
‚Ä¢ nah, your milk was totally not left out way longer than it should have because I'm the only person here who has to stock freezers, and dairy, and run the register. 

MORE CONS IN ADVICE BELOW
advice_to_management:
Oh where do I even begin. 
1. Drop the "unionizing is bad act" for those who do not know, when you unionize, it means you get treated with respect and DG will be forced to you know, give you a livable wage. 
2. Maybe pay the unconventional pay rate. If everyone else is being paid $15, don't pay some of your employees the actual minimum wage and expect them to be bend over backwards. 
3. Stop penalizing your store managers for the loss of product. What do you expect when you place your locations in low-income areas and have insanely high prices. 
4. Penalize store managers for time theft. They're not always leaving when they should, nor are they always showing up too. Make them clock in like the rest of us. 
5. HIRE MORE EMPLOYEES, minimum of three workers per shift, when people call out, then it becomes a problem which leads me into my next one.
6. More employees = more coverage, neater stores, less theft. You expect employees to be ringing up customers, leads to stock and also keep on register and expect employees to watch for theft? Wild. 
7. If the store managers get a bonus for their inventory, why don't the employees either? You want your inventory to be better, we'll give your employees who are actually doing the work a bonus too. You guys can give $100 to customers who complain but can't do the same for your employees? Yes I literally WITNESSED this. 
8. ERC/HR is a joke. You have so many automated areas it's genuinely CANT get in contact with the right people. HR will send you to ERC, and ERC would end up confused why HR didn't handle something they can't. 
9. Your HR employees actually f**cking suck. Enough said. 
10. Work-life balance, do you really expect me, and any other employees to cover the store managers a** when it's their job to run their store, but instead they force their other employees who probably just pulled a 7 day work day to come in?
11. There's a good reason why you guys start your new pay start dates on Saturday and I'm not dumb. It's to deter employees from not working weekends. 
12. Mental health, of you know it's bad when an employee is on the urge of offing themselves and your store managers only concern is who's going to fill your shift
13. The only time your damn stores are nice is during inventory. I wonder why they are, maybe because you have the district manager, and 4 other store managers AND the normal employees working all at once. Wow shocking. 
14. All employees should accumulate PTO and sick time. End of story. Your full time employees aren't the only ones working full-time. 
15. Easter, Thanksgiving and Christmas? Are you joking? It's crazy how all of these days are religious says, not like fourth of July isn't important when most of your parents or anyone wants to be there. But no, let's let them work normal hours. Or you know, memorial day? What happened to the care of your veterans now? Or let's even talk about labor day, and maybe Juneteenth, and you know what, let's even add NEW YEARS. Cheapskates. 
16. Why is it only your full-time employees get paid automatically 8 hours on holidays and now part-time, even if it's the one day out of 365 days that you're closed, Christmas. Oh on top of that, if the full-time employee wants to pick up a holiday they still get that 8 hours on top of the time-in-a-half? 
17. Overworking your loss prevention and your own district managers is a whole different level of stupid. 


Let's get to the actual point. Your CEO makes millions and millions of dollars just to underpay your employees, understaff stores, and to give the big bucks to your store managers who either A. Time theft or B. So overworked they mentally break. Maybe change that, food for thought. Health inspections, mandatory. Give your workers the holiday pay of all federal holidays, maybe then they'll want to show up. Restart your paydays on Sunday, this gives store managers the opportunity to work employees EVERY OTHER WEEKEND, give them you know, a break? CLEAN and MAINTAIN a store. Why in the hell is an ASM job to beg the district manager for someone to redo the asphalt and lines in the parking lot? All of your cigarettes should have a pulldown and lock option. Maybe then people wouldn't be so eager to break in, idk. All stores need their panic buttons back. Would have saved me, and my old coworkers from being assaulted. No employees should be by themselves, doesn't matter what time of day it is. 15 unpaid break, and 30 paid if hours are acceptable. Oh yeah, just so everyone knows they definitely are overcharging you. Target and Family Dollar have better and lower prices. On top of that, any family dollar I've been in thus far, it has been so clean and smooth, yes even in the low-income areas. 

At the end of the day, you'll never do this. Because you don't care, as long as you price gouge poor people. Make them so desperate they endure physical and verbal abuse. This is the worse company to work for.

title: Worst Company

cons:

They will have you doing everything from opening, closing, money counting, training over and over bc the turn over is of course very high, checking in vendors, stalking, cleaning, sweeping and mopping the store, the weekly add. putting up a very large cold food truck once a week by yourself. They will tell you that they are going to pay you x amount an hour but do not end up following through. They just hire your replacement and expect you to train them. 

They take advantage of disabled and young employees the most.

 You can‚Äôt afford a box of uncrustables if purchased from them after working an hour there. Also, if you do shop there make sure you check what you are purchasing. title: It's Fine
pros: Whether you are looking for your first job or something on the side it is fine getting into, the work is not difficult and the atmosphere is generally laid back. The majority of the people you work with should be fairy laid back and easy to get along with to help build a strong culture. So long as you are proficient you can work at various locations and be compensated for travel, though in some districts those opportunities are harder to come by.
cons: The company is not afraid to outsource for positions of District Manager or greater, and so mobility can be rather stagnant at times. Additionally stores are occasionally under budgeted for working hours, as they have a system in which certain positions essentially get counted as a 1 and 3/4 person, so some peak business hours can feel understaffed as a result. Stores also have not received additional scheduling hours to compensate for the removal of self checkout from nearly a year ago. Associates don't receive much communication beyond their store managers as well, leading to a disconnect between District Managers and those at Assistant Store Manager and below.
advice_to_management: Promote from within and budget more hours for store locations that relied on self-checkout prior to its removal. Have consistent standards of each store within districts.

title: Toxic and lacking integrity
pros: The role was never too challenging nor engaging.  The company has a professional environment with a basic benefits package.
cons:
My experience was marred by a significant breach of trust from leadership. I was actively encouraged by my manager and Sr. manager to apply for a role in another department, receiving weeks of support and well-wishes during the interview process. I confirmed with the hiring director that I was selected to move forward, only to be blindsided by my leadership team placing me on a performance improvement plan (PIP) to block my transfer a few days later. It became clear my management team leveraged their connections with HR. These are not trustworthy people nor is the department. There's a reason this role has had roughly 8 people over the last 5yrs.

The role is not hard, but working for this leadership team can be very unhealthy. I would highly advise you look elsewhere.

title: Company doesn't care about its employees
pros: There are good people at the company, and it's consistent and stable. Flex scheduling makes it possible to manage life to some small degree, though it's not as good as it was when the company was work from home.
cons: Company operates on a lean, skeleton crew ideology. There is never proactive staffing for growing business needs. The company has refused to pay bonuses for 2 years despite record breaking profits of over 1 billion. The company does not make cost of living increases, and annual pay raises are arbitrarily assigned and can be as low as .5%, or refused entirely. The company participates in union busting efforts and recently forced a mandatory return to office despite the fact that nearly all corporate employees had been WFH for 5 years. When I started at the company, their salaries and benefits were competitive in the market, but they have failed to keep up with cost of living. They also have recently begun "cost saving" layoffs, despite being on track for over $1 billion in profits.
advice_to_management: Lower management at the company is supportive and cares, but upper management either doesn't care about the rank and file, or they are being forced to enact harmful decisions by the board. Employees need a living wage, and if the company continues to show that it doesn't value its employees, it's going to lose all of its talent.

title: You're worth more than this
pros: The other people there were hard-working and impressive in all that they managed.
cons: The way corporate manages hours forces understaffing. We could have enough people to fully staff all shifts, but the manager wouldn't be allowed to schedule enough hours to do so. Corporate changes systems with little to no notice and is carelessly unsupportive to those who run their locations. I applied and was hired as a part-time employee, but by the time I left I was working 40-50 hours as a shift lead, almost always only having one other employee in the store. They still expect stocking, organizing, cashiering, cleaning, on-the-floor assistance, and more to be done constantly throughout each day. I watched managers work themselves to the point of collapse. No one should feel that they are worth so little to deserve a job like this. I worked there for half a year and by the time I left I had the most experience out of anyone still there, with the exception of my manager. People don't last there very long, and it's almost never their fault.
advice_to_management: It doesn't matter how good the management is when corporate refuses to treat any of you with any decency.

title: Overall good place but a few disadvantages

title: Terrible Pay, unrealistic expectations
pros: Some coworkers were nice, locations was close to home, did enjoy knowing deals ahead of time tho
cons:
Terrible pay, they expect you to be on call for the fresh truck but dont pay you any extra for it OR you dont get paid if the truck happens to not be able to make its delivery on time, make you work on every single holiday except for Christmas day, nor do the hours get shortened on those days either. Only some holidays got holiday pay. No sick pay, no PTO, no vacation days, no actual benefical benefits. No employee discount (except like maybe 3 times a year where they decide to give you 30% off that is not combinable with any other coupons and only could be used once). Management would make up stupid rules or decide to enforce rules that only applied to certain people and only when they benefitted them. Make you buy your own uniforms then have the audacity to put up signs for uniforms you could buy 

The higher ups literally do not care to listen to anyone on any complaints or suggestions we had. They just came in, not knowing literally anything about how the store worked and then forced us to change everything--which ended up making everything more difficult for customers and employees.
advice_to_management: Stand up to the district managers. And district managers could actually take our complaints seriously. Also raise the pay for literally everyone? And do actual benefits. And something needs to be done about the warehouse and how they ship stuff to the stores. We would get like insane amounts of toilet paper and other things and have no where to put them.

title: I dont and would not refer anyone to Bristol locations.
pros: Meet new people every day
cons:
90% of employees are part time so they dont have to provide benefits. DG believes 3 to 4 people working part time is fully staffed. Store managers are not trained correctly. Turnover rate is high bc the expected work to be done is impossible to keep up with only getting 25 hours a week. We went 3 months with no store manager and the year i was there i had 4 different store managers .
When they dont like you they wright you up constantly. Unsafe stocking methods. Freight is always on floors in boxes. Some employees just stick boxes on the shelves instead of stocking it properly.  Dont expect store managers to help out. They just point and tell you to do a job while they stand there on their phones or sit in the security office and watch camaras.
advice_to_management: My advise would be to district managers to train the correct people for Store Management and to make sure they do their job.

title: Understaffed and terrible training practices.
pros: I'm sure there's some somewhere
cons:
I was recently hired and my experience training has been terrible.  I had exactly one four hour shift where I was given the time to work on my training modules.  The very next shift, I was on register and doing recovery/closing procedures while also having to do the training modules.  
My store is chronically understaffed. 99% of the time there is the bare minimum of employees (2) in the store.   Typically, with one person working the register and one working Receiving and/or Recovery or doing chores .  I was doing my modules while also being the only person on the front end.  
Apparently I also need to get them done to stay employed because it's a problem that I haven't finished mine.
I haven't gotten the modules done because I haven't had the time.

title: Selling your soul
pros: The cashier's were great and so was the freight thrower.
cons: I was told 48 hrs before being hired and I worked 48 hrs a wk for the first 2 weeks. Then 60 and then 72 hrs a wk. I worked 6 days a wk and extremely long days. The backroom was full when I started and no matter how hard I worked, that never changed. I was expected to set pogs, end caps, run register, paperwork, schedules and all the while with only 117 labor hours a wk. Each week, I was told to cut labor and that made it impossible for me to get anything done. They are the worst company hands down to work for. I got to see my husband maybe 2 hours tops a day and I had to miss my daughter's events because of this place.
advice_to_management: If you want to know why there is a high turn over rate for store manager's then I suggest you look at the workload that DM's are placing on the SM's and staff.
